channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: The Future is Now! Perl Role in Malaysia
item.description: Our client is an online financial services company, still rapidly expanding after 20 years of impressive growth. With a truly international presence, they’re well known globally in their niche. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: Vienna Does it Best. Perl Developer role in Vienna
item.description: As one of the largest and most trusted product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries, our client has made it their mission to save people from overpaying. Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: Cooking Up Something Good. Perl role in London
item.description: If your mouth is watering at the thought of joining this dynamic team and you’re a senior Perl programmer with a solid understanding of Go programming languages, they just might set a place for you at the table. Bonus if you know Python, have experience with frameworks like Django, and a strong understanding of databases like MySQL and NoSQL databases like Google BigTable.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: Attention, Perl programmers. We’re looking for those among you who loved their childhood chemistry sets and could spend hours studying their ant farms. Science buffs and genetics junkies, our client wants to hear from you. You’ll be familiar with modern tooling and might have experience with Ansible, AWS, and Linux containers. MySQL, Postgres, and Solr are all nice-to-haves.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. Applicants, bring your “A” game: they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and can evaluate NLP systems.

item.title: Working on PyDigger with Upasana Shukla - part 3
item.description: PyDigger is a Python-based project.

item.title: Build Docker image in GitLab CI/CD pipeline
Crystal part 2 - puts, print, p!
item.description: Learning to program in Crystal language

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Create a lexical warning that can be turned on and off with the "warnings" pragma.
Weekly Challenge 117
item.description: Thanks Simon for talking about Shroder Number. I didn't know about it. I learn so much by just reading the blogs by Team PWC. Thank you for your effort.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 117: Missing Possibilities
item.description: I loved the graphical representation of the Find Possible Paths task. It helped a lot to understand the solution. Thanks for all your hard work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 117
item.description: Luis showed the power of recursive funtion when dealing with Find Possible Paths task. Nice and easy to follow, thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 117: quick and dirty
item.description: Luca's Raku solution to the Find Possible Paths is the my favourite this week. The code looks elegant. Thanks for your efforts.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 117: Missing Row and Possible Paths
item.description: Laurent presented us this week, short and precise solutions, specially the solution to the Find Possible Paths. He made it look so simple. Great work, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #117
item.description: I always look for James solution and his story behind the solution. He is so good at looking beyond the task and give his opinions. I simply loved it. Keep it going.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 117
item.description: I loved the explanation of Find Possible Paths solution. It is easy to follow for any layman. Thanks for your efforts. BTW congratulations on the second anniversay of your blogging.

item.title: Perl Challenge 117 Redux: Permutations!
item.description: This is bonus blog from Dave to give a detailed analysis of the task Find Possible Paths. Thanks for the blog.

item.title: Trees and Rows: Perl Weekly Challenge 117
item.description: I loved the fact that Dave generating the input file on the fly. Nice hack. Also his idea of re-using his past solution and extending it to get the task done. Very clever approach.

item.title: PWC117 - Find Possible Paths
item.description: Flavio extensive discussion on Find Possible Paths task is something you don't want to miss. It is the kind of discussion I always look for in a PWC blog. Thank you Flavio.

item.title: PWC117 - Missing Row
item.description: Flavio regex magic for Missing Rows task is mind blowing. It took me sometime to understand. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Who Went Missing on the Triangular Tour?
item.description: As always, Colin story behind each task is so priceless, you don't want to miss. He is simply the best. Keep it going. Thanks.

item.title: The Rowdy Path with Raku and Perl
item.description: Ever since Arne started sharing Perl solution alongwith Raku, I really enjoy the translation of Raku to get the Perl equivalent. Great work. Keep it up.

item.title: A List with One Missing Line and Too Many Lines to List: The Weekly Challenge 117
item.description: Credit must be given to Adam for printing the structured triangle and introducing the Qauntam Pascal Triangle. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 117
item.description: Enjoy quick recap of last week contributions by the Team PWC dealing with the "Missing Rows" and "Find Possible Paths" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 118
item.description: Welcome new week with couple of fun tasks "Binary Palindrome" and "Adventure of Knight". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: The Perl echo chamber, marketing and ... is Perl really dying?
item.description: here

item.title: 4 Steps to Blogging Outside the Perl Bubble
item.description: Mark has been one of the most prolific writer about Perl recently. You might want to listen to him.

item.title: Data visualization: Creating charts using REST API's in React.js
item.description: Part of the MojoReactApp-OpenAPI series.

item.title: PAUSE workaround
item.description: PAUSE parses the text in your code to see which modules you provide. Unfortunately that means it also includes names that are only mentiond in the documentation or in strings that never get executed. This can lead to unpleasant side-effects. How can you avoid these?

item.title: One complete year, yay!
item.description: Only one year? It feels as if Flavio has been posting for ages... Congratulations!

item.title: #517 - Commitment and habit
item.description:
Hi there!

Flavio Poletti has just completed one year of blogging. Mohammad S. Anwar has been editing the Perl Weekly for more than 3 years and running the Perl Weekly Challenge for more than 2 years.

I am not sure what is the secret, but something about creating a commitment, even if it is an artificial commitment that then you need to stick to. I am sure both of them had times when they though of sleeping in and not doing the work that day or that week. After all this is not their paid job, but the commitment kept them going. With time it became easier to do the task and the whole thing became a habit. I wish more people found the strength to do something like this.

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
